title: Could a no-deal Brexit still happen?
text:
Protesters demonstrate outside Westminster as parliament sits on a Saturday for the first time since 1982 to discuss Brexit (Picture: Reuters)

Super Saturday opened with Boris Johnson making a last minute plea to MPs to pass his new Brexit deal during a historic House of Commons sitting.

But there are fears that even if Mr Johnson’s deal is approved today, Parliament could run out of time to pass all the necessary legal steps.

Some critics of Boris Johnson suspect he is ‘duping’ MPs into backing him, and he will simply run down the clock and leave without an arrangement by the end of the transition period in December 2020.

But how likely is this scenario?

Could a no-deal Brexit still happen?

Potentially.

Under the terms of the Withdrawal Agreement made by the government and the EU in October 2019, the UK will enter a transition period when it leaves the EU.

This was the same in the Withdrawal Agreement negotiated by Theresa May’s government (which was voted down by parliament three times.)

The purpose of the transition period is to provide time for the UK and the EU to negotiate on what their future relationship will look like.

Trade talks are supposed to happen within the transition period – but we could still leave with no-deal if they fail.

Sir Oliver Letwin has put forward an amendment that could block today’s Brexit vote. (Picture: AFP)

Former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin is trying to add an amendment to today’s vote which would withhold approval of the deal unless and until implementing legislation has passed.

This keeps the Benn Act extension in place until all the legal boxes are ticked and would prevent an ‘accidental no-deal departure.’

The Benn Act was passed by MPs earlier this year, and forced the government to seek a three month extension to the EU deadline if no new withdrawal agreement was made before October 31st.

What happens if the new deal is rejected?

Advertisement

Advertisement

That is not the only scenario under which a no-deal could happen.

MPs have until October 31st to agree to a new Brexit deal.

Unless the EU grant and extension to that deadline, the UK could end up leaving with a no-deal by default.

A no-deal is still possible if MPs reject today’s vote (Picture: AFP)

Although bills have been passed to force the government to seek an extension, there is no guarantee the EU will grant this.

If the Withdrawal Agreement is passed by parliament and the transition period kicks in that doesn’t mean the possibility of no deal is removed entirely—it just means a different kind of no deal.
